messageBody:
On 8/16/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Hi Simon,
>
> On 8/16/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > Generally, you get as much code as possible out of the GUI, so that
> > the extracted code can be easily tested the old fashioned way. Domain
> > (business) objects that are easily testable and a very thin GUI that
> > is difficult to test beats a thick GUI that's difficult to test.
> >
> > Someone else will have to advise you about the best GUI testing tools.
> > I've never needed to use one.
>
>
> Do you mean that you released GUI software without ever automatically
> testing the graphic part?

I've never written GUI code, is what I meant. That's why I've never
needed a GUI tester.

> That's very surprising (almost unprofessional :-)).

Yes, it would be. :-)

> Having your business objects tested is nice, but it's the easy part. How do
> you guarantee that when the user presses the "Ok" button, the program works
> as expected?

Agreed. Hence my recommendation to get them out of the GUI. Make the
"hard to test" part as small as possible.

> On a side topic, testing GUI's is also a domain where TDD is very hard to
> achieve, but let's keep that discussion in the other thread :-)

I imagine it is. Thankfully, I've never had to write any GUI code.

Simon
